Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Rejection
Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess best interests of the child
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of PRRA Officer's decision on H&C application
Application_Facts: Family fled Guyana after a violent home invasion; children witnessed mother's attack; long-term residence in Canada; reintegration challenges in Guyana
Decision_Outcome: Rejection of H&C application by PRRA Officer
Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident applicants under H&C grounds
Defendant_Behavior: PRRA Officer applied incorrect legal test ('unusual hardship') and failed to assess psychological trauma to children
Grounds_for_Claim: Best interests of the children, psychological harm upon return, family unity, reintegration difficulties
Legal_Standard: Best interests of the child must be assessed independently without 'unusual, undeserved or disproportionate hardship' test
Assessment_Factor: Psychological impact on children, length of residence in Canada, safety concerns in Guyana
Procedural_Issue: Use of incorrect legal framework in assessment
Evidence_Used: Details of violent home invasion, children's attachment to Canada, lack of support system in Guyana
Application_Basis: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under s. 25(1)
Evidence_Assessed: Trauma experienced by family, stability in Canada, risks upon return
Relief_Sought: Re-determination of H&C application by a different PRRA Officer
Governing_Rule: Best interests of the child must be primary consideration
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to address psychological trauma and used improper hardship test
Outcome: Decision set aside; remitted to a different Officer for re-assessment
Harm_Assessment: Children would suffer psychological trauma if returned to Guyana
Cause_Description: Family fled Guyana due to a violent home invasion and sought protection in Canada on humanitarian grounds
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient consideration of trauma and integration evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 25(1) - failure to consider best interests of the child
Evidence_Issues: Failure to properly evaluate psychological evidence regarding children
Evidence_Assessment: Inadequate assessment of hardship and best interests factors
Decision_Rationale: Use of incorrect legal test and failure to analyze key factors rendered decision unreasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Omission of critical psychological and humanitarian factors
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unreasonable application of 'unusual hardship' instead of independent best interests analysis
